text.text: Pro-russische Demonstration in KÃ¶ln
Pro-russische Demonstration in KÃ¶ln
In KÃ¶ln haben nach Angaben der Polizei etwa 400 pro-russische Demonstranten gegen deutsche Waffenlieferungen in die Ukraine protestiert.

Sprecher rechtfertigten den russischen Angriffskrieg gegen die Ukraine als notwendige Selbstverteidigung Russlands. Die Demonstranten forderten ein Ende der Sanktionen gegen Russland und die Inbetriebnahme der Gaspipeline Nordstream 2. An der Demonstration beteiligten sich neben vielen Deutsch-Russen auch bekannte Rechtsradikale aus Nordrhein-Westfalen und Ostdeutschland. 
Am Rande der Demonstration protestierten mehrere hundert Menschen gegen die pro-russische Kundgebung. Die Polizei war mit einem GroÃŸaufgebot im Einsatz. Vereinzelt wurden Flaschen und FeuerwerkskÃ¶rper in Richtung des Demonstrationszuges geworfen. Ansonsten verlief die Demonstration ohne ZwischenfÃ¤lle.

â—Embassy comment on another anti-Russian statement by the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office 

â–ªï¸ The Embassy has taken note of yet another anti-Russian statement by the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office, this time questioning Russiaâ€™s â€œmoral rightâ€ to sit at the G20. We consider this a sign of Londonâ€™s apparent despair amid the deadlocked efforts of British foreign policy to impose a perception of our country being internationally isolated on the global community. 

â–ªï¸ We are puzzled to hear teachings about â€œmoral rightsâ€ from a country, whose colonial crimes, committed almost in all corners of the former â€œempire on which the sun never setâ€, are still the subject of extensive studies and discussion around the world. If we start talking about morality, a legitimate question arises â€“ by what right does the UK sit at the G20 alongside some countries which had in the past suffered themselves from the predatory, aggressive and bloody wars unleashed by London, the deception and looting of their people, as well as the massive removal of their national assets and cultural attractions. 

â–ªï¸ We consider such statements especially hypocritical after the UK, together with NATO allies discredited itself by actively participating in illegal and aggressive military campaigns in Yugoslavia, Iraq, Libya and Syria, as well as in other countries of the Middle East and Africa. We would also like to recall the recent BBC investigations of war crimes committed by British soldiers in Afghanistan. 

â–ªï¸We are well aware of the motives pushing the so-called â€œcollective Westâ€, including the UK, to persist with futile attempts to restore the former comfortable monopoly in international affairs and, for this purpose, to settle scores with independent states that conduct a sovereign policy based on national interests. In this regard we have to remind the FCDO that Western countries today account for only about 12Â % of the world's population. 

â–ªï¸We call on London to stop undermining the foundations of a successfully established and strengthening polycentric world order, with the G20 being one of its constituent parts, and to demonstrate a responsible and respectful approach to other countries and nations.

La situaciÃ³n en el mundo cambia dinÃ¡micamente y se conforman los contornos de un orden mundial multipolar.

Las Ã©lites occidentales luchan contra estos procesos objetivos provocando el caos, alimentando conflictos, y llevando a cabo su llamada polÃ­tica de contenciÃ³n. AsÃ­ intentan preservar la hegemonÃ­a y el poder que se les escapan de las manos y mantener a los paÃ­ses y pueblos en las garras del orden neocolonial.

ðŸŽ™ Statement by Permanent Representative Vassily Nebenzia at UNSC briefing regarding the attacks of Ukrainian armed forces on the Zaporozhye NPP

Read in full

ðŸ”¹ Ukrainian armed forces have used heavy artillery and multiple launch rocket systems against the biggest nuclear power plant in Europe â€“ the Zaporozhye NPP.

ðŸ”¹ Developments at the ZNPP these days are the climax of Kiev's criminal actions against nuclear infrastructure and personnel servicing nuclear facilities.

ðŸ”¹ From the very start, we supported the IAEA efforts aimed at ensuring safety and security of Ukrainian nuclear facilities.

ðŸ”¹ We carefully observe the mentioned seven principles and do our best to let IAEA representatives make sure of that themselves.

ðŸ”¹ Heinous attacks by Kiev against nuclear facilities push the world onto the brink of a nuclear disaster, the scope of which would be comparable to that of the Chernobyl tragedy.

â—ï¸ We call on the states that support the Kiev regime to check their proteges, make them stop attacking the ZNPP and residents of Energodar once and for all.

â—ï¸ We urge the top officials of the United Nations and IAEA to demonstrate their leadership and global responsibility and indicate clearly and without diplomatic courtesies the real source of the threat to the safety and security of the ZNPP.

ðŸ›‘ The Ukrainian nationalists have recently intensified the shelling of residential areas in Donbass, now use even anti-personnel munition, the so-called butterfly mines. 

The use of butterfly mines goes against the Additional Protocol to the Geneva Convention Relative to the Protection of Civilian Persons in Time of War of August 12, 1949.

The fact that the Ukrainian nationalists even possess butterfly mines speaks volumes. By signing the 1997 Ottawa Convention, Ukraine made a commitment not to use anti-personnel mines under any circumstances, not even on the battlefield, and to destroy all stocks of such mines held in arsenals. 

Apparently, Kiev has not done any of that.
 
On August 1, Russiaâ€™s Permanent Mission to the UN sent the information about the use of butterfly mines by Ukraine to UNSG Antonio Guterres and the head of the Security Council. The letter with attached photographic evidence will be distributed as an official document of the UNSC & UNGA.

ðŸ‡§ðŸ‡·ðŸ‡·ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡®ðŸ‡³ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡³ðŸ‡¿ðŸ‡¦ BRICS is based on our common commitment to the values of equal dialogue and cooperation, and the mutual affinity of our unique cultures and civilisations, which represent different parts of the planet. Our association provides an example of a truly multilateral and multipolar diplomacy concordant with the realities of the 21st century. 

The development of cultural, educational and sports ties is aimed at strengthening the atmosphere of friendship and trust among the peoples of our five countries. We traditionally pay much attention to ties between our young people. Our interaction in this sphere is vivid proof of the vitality and great appeal of the BRICS concept.

Russian Foreign Ministry statement on US House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosiâ€™s visit to Taiwan

Speaker of the US House of Representatives, Nancy Pelosi, arrived in Taiwan on August 2. 

 We consider her visit a clear provocation in keeping with the USâ€™s aggressive policy of comprehensive containment of the PRC.

We believe relations between both sides of the Taiwan Strait are exclusively Chinaâ€™s domestic affair. The Chinese side is entitled to take any measures necessary to protect its sovereignty and territorial integrity in terms of the Taiwan issue.

 Russia's principled position remains unchanged: we operate on the premise that there is only one China, and the PRC government is the only legitimate government representing all of China, and that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China.

In the Joint Statement of the Russian Federation and the People's Republic of China on international relations entering a new era and on sustainable global development, which was adopted after the talks between the leaders of our countries on February 4, the Russian side reaffirmed its adherence to the â€œone Chinaâ€ principle and opposed the independence of the island in any form.

We call on Washington to refrain from actions, that undermine regional stability and international security, and to recognise the new geopolitical reality, which has no place for US hegemony.

#WeStandWithChina
#ThereIsOnlyOneChina

texts.text: La selecciÃ³n masculina cubana de voleibol venciÃ³ a TurquÃ­a en la final de la Copa Challenger y

text.text: por primera vez en su historia clasificÃ³ a la Liga de Naciones, el torneo Ã©lite de este deporte a nivel mundial.

texts.text: En el evento efectuado en Sudcorea los caribeÃ±os

text.text: solo cedieron un set en sus tres partidos

texts.text: y confirmaron los progresos de un deporte que recupera el terreno perdido.

En el duelo que definÃ­a el boleto Cuba abriÃ³ con su cuadro titular, compuesto por el pasador AdriÃ¡n Goide, los auxiliares Miguel Ãngel LÃ³pez y Osniel Mergarejo, el opuesto JesÃºs Herrera, los centrales Roamy Alonso y Javier ConcepciÃ³n y Yonder GarcÃ­a como lÃ­bero. Sin embargo,

text.text: tras el fÃ¡cil dominio de 25-17 durante del primer set,

texts.text: en el segundo la distribuciÃ³n del ataque no funcionÃ³ igual y LivÃ¡n Taboada asumiÃ³ el pase.
Aun asÃ­, en definitiva

text.text: los antillanos no lograron descontar lo suficiente y ese parcial cerrÃ³ 23-25 en su contra.

texts.text: Un menor trabajo en la net y una inestabilidad en el servicio tambiÃ©n confluyeron para igualar el duelo a un set para cada conjunto.
Durante la tercera manga el conjunto antillano mostrÃ³ otra vez la fuerza de la apertura y saliÃ³ airoso con pizarra de 25-20. Los

text.text: seis puntos del capitÃ¡n Miguel Ãngel LÃ³pez y los cuatro per cÃ¡pita para Javier ConcepciÃ³n y JesÃºs Herrera

texts.text: apuntalaron una mejor recepciÃ³n y una aceptable defensa de campo.
De esta forma todo quedÃ³ listo para el cuarto set,

text.text: finalmente decisivo para los cubanos tras su victoria con idÃ©ntico marcador de 25-20.

texts.text: Alli apenas dieron oportunidades a sus rivales y tomaron ventaja desde los primeros compases, otra vez

text.text: aupados por los seis tantos de Miguel Ãngel, la solidez de Herrera y los aportes ofensivos de un Osniel Mergarejo que con su servicio desestabilizÃ³ mucho a la defensa rival.
El bloqueo fue otra arma cubana. Foto: Volleyball World.

texts.text: De acuerdo a las estadÃ­sticas del partido

text.text: el equipo caribeÃ±o fue mejor en todos los aspectos de juego salvo en la recepciÃ³n

texts.text: , el tradicional punto dÃ©bil de las escuadras nacionales pero que durante todo el torneo, incluyendo el juego final, tambiÃ©n mostrÃ³ sus progresos.
En el orden individual,

text.text: Miguel Ãngel LÃ³pez y el opuesto JesÃºs Herrera asumieron el peso ofensivo con 20 y 19 puntos, respectivamente.

texts.text: Junto a ellos, los doce tantos del central Roamy Alonso y los once de Mergarejo, incluyendo cuatro

text.text: aces

texts.text: , tambiÃ©n contribuyeron al Ã©xito. De igual manera, merece los aplausos

text.text: la excepcional de defensa del lÃ­bero Yonder MartÃ­nez, con una efectividad del cien por ciento en este partido.

texts.text: En un torneo donde la Isla solo perdiÃ³ un set y derrotÃ³ por su orden a Chile y RepÃºblica Checa para llegar a la final,
Mergarejo y Miguel Ãngel terminaron como lÃ­deres en el servicio, con seis

text.text: aces

texts.text: cada uno.
Mientras, el propio Miguel Ãlngel cerrÃ³ tercero entre los mejores anotadores (50 puntos) y entre los bloqueadores (7).
Al finalizar el choque el capitÃ¡n cubano dijo

text.text: sentirse feliz por conseguir el cupo â€”antes Cuba terminÃ³ cuarta en 2018 y segunda en 2019â€” y reconociÃ³ a TurquÃ­a por el partido.

texts.text: â€œSin embargo, nosotros tambiÃ©n mantuvimos la concentraciÃ³n e hicimos un buen juego. Llegar a la Liga de Naciones significa mucho, porque llevÃ¡bamos varios aÃ±os sin participar en la Ã©lite.

text.text: Es un honor y un gran logro representar a Cuba en un torneo como esteâ€

texts.text: , concluyÃ³.
Esta clasificaciÃ³n a la Liga de las Naciones de 2023 no solo representarÃ¡ el debut de una escuadra cubana en esta competencia, sino que
es ya lo mejor conseguido por la selecciÃ³n nacional desde su presencia en los Juegos OlÃ­mpicos de 2016, la Liga Mundial de ese aÃ±o, mÃ¡s tarde la cita universal de 2018 y el propio torneo

texts.text: Desde entonces,

text.text: el voleibol cubano labrÃ³ un camino enfocado en la inserciÃ³n de jugadores en diferentes ligas y clubes del planeta

texts.text: , asÃ­ como de acercamiento a quienes en un momento solicitaron baja de los equipos criollos, pero mostraron disposiciÃ³n de regresar. Esa dualidad, junto a un sostenido trabajo en la base y en categorÃ­as inferiores,

text.text: comienza ahora a mostrar y consolidar sus resultados.

messages.message:
Today Russia celebrates #NavyDay, July 31, by tradition on the last Sunday of this summer month.

For 326 years the Navy safeguarded our nation's interests and borders. It has come a long way â€“ from wooden two-masted flat-bottomed boats of Peter the Greatâ€™s era, to formidable nuclear underwater missile cruisers.

The true foundation of the Russian naval traditions was laid on October 30, 1696 when the Boyar Duma, upon the request of Peter the Great, approved his decree on the construction of a navy. 

â€œThe Russian Navy shall set sail.â€

Learn more about the Russian Navy's history, traditions and capabilities.

This year St Petersburg per tradition hosts the Main Naval Parade in honour of the Day. 40+ warships and submarines will take part in it. The pride of our fleet can be seen in the Neva River in the centre of St Petersburg, and at Kronstadt â€“ where big surface vessels, which cannot enter the Neva River due to their size, can be viewed. 

#RussianNavy

webpage.title: The lights are going out across Europe
webpage.description: The EUâ€™s plan for mandatory gas rationing is utterly terrifying.
webpage.author: Fraser Myers

text.text: The lights are going out across Europe
The EUâ€™s plan for mandatory gas rationing is utterly terrifying.

The EUâ€™s 27 member states â€“ all modern, advanced industrialised economies, some among the richest in the world â€“ are about to start rationing their energy supplies. This week, at an extraordinary summit, EU members agreed to a European Commission proposal to slash their gas use by a punishing 15 per cent over the next eight months. From August 2022 to March 2023, the lamps will, quite literally, be going out all over Europe.

texts.text: The immediate spur for this is the prospect of Russia limiting or even cutting off supplies of gas to the EU. According to European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen, even this worst-case, nightmare scenario is â€˜likelyâ€™. European leaders were particularly spooked earlier this month when the Nord Stream 1 gas pipeline, which supplies Russian gas to Germany, had to be shut down for 10 days for repairs. They were afraid it would

text.text: never reopen

texts.text: The EUâ€™s punishing plan is designed to get Europe through the winter, should the Russians do the unthinkable and turn off the taps completely. If the crisis deepens, voluntary gas cuts could become

text.text: mandatory

texts.text: . The European Commission of unelected technocrats has also explored the use of emergency protocols which could block any country from exercising a veto on mandatory gas cuts and would also prevent the European Parliament from having a say.
As

text.text: Politico
reported

texts.text: in the run-up to this weekâ€™s summit, European governments were â€˜being asked to sign over their right to energy sovereigntyâ€™, in Brusselsâ€™ â€˜most far-reaching power grabâ€™ yet. And with some exemptions â€“ for nations not connected to the EUâ€™s gas and electricity networks â€“ this is exactly what has happened. European countries now face crippling energy cuts â€“ first self-inflicted, then potentially imposed by Brussels.
Yet in the eyes of the Brussels spin machine, this gas-rationing catastrophe is EU â€˜solidarityâ€™ and â€˜unityâ€™ in action. Or even, in the excitable words of European Commission vice-president

text.text: Frans Timmermans

texts.text: , a golden opportunity for Europeans to become â€˜masters of our own energy security this and next winterâ€™. This is through-the-looking-glass stuff.

text.text: It is hard to overstate the madness of all this. This should not be mistaken for a bold or selfless move to sanction Russia for its horrific invasion of Ukraine. The EU had already agreed to cut Russian gas imports by two-thirds back in March, and to ban 90 per cent of oil imports back in May. No, this plan is about slashing Europeâ€™s use of gas, wherever it is from. It is about managing Europeansâ€™ â€˜demandâ€™ for energy rather than fixing its supply.

And while all of Europe is dangerously dependent on Russian gas â€“ with Russia supplying 40 per cent of imports last year â€“ the main concern is Germany. Indeed, it is the worldâ€™s largest importer of natural gas, 55 per cent of which came from Russia last year. It is Germany that this plan really sets out to rescue.

Germany is already having to make drastic cutbacks to energy use. Town councils are dimming or turning off street lights and even traffic lights. Large landlords and housing associations have started turning down the heating on their residents and rationing their hot water. Some local authorities are considering setting up â€˜warm roomsâ€™ for elderly people to gather in the winter.

texts.text: Even Germanyâ€™s much-vaunted industrial sector â€“ powered largely by gas â€“ is now facing the abyss. Germany now has a trade deficit for the first time in 30 years. Trade-union leaders fear the

text.text: collapse of entire industries

texts.text: . Green Party economy minister Robert Habeck has

text.text: warned

texts.text: of an impending â€˜Lehman Brothers-styleâ€™ crisis, triggered by gas shortages, that could send shockwaves through the wider economy. And foreign minister Annalena Baerbock even said the government could be â€˜busyâ€™ this winter dealing with â€˜popular uprisingsâ€™ (though she has since retracted this).

text.text: So clearly, Germany is in a deep crisis. And via the EU, it is asking (or strong-arming) its European neighbours to share some of the pain.

texts.text: Some fellow member-states were quick to spot the irony in what is effectively an energy bailout of Germany. This is the same Germany that, during the Eurozone debt crisis of the 2010s, insisted that indebted countries had only themselves and their profligacy to blame. Bailouts were offered but strict austerity measures and so-called structural reforms were attached, which laid waste to the southern European economies. The economies of Greece, Italy and Spain have never recovered to their pre-2010 levels. As Spainâ€™s energy minister put it, when hitting back against the proposals last week: â€˜Unlike other countries [ie, Germany] we have not been living above our energy means.â€™ Spain was joined by a host of other southern countries in voicing public opposition to the energy-rationing plans. But, as the Spanish energy minister acknowledged, whatever her protestations, the core proposals were really â€˜a

text.text: fait accompli

texts.text: â€™. Berlin usually rules in Brussels, after all. At this weekâ€™s council meeting, though southern Europe was able to draw some concessions, only Hungary actually voted against the plan.

text.text: Those southern Europeans are right to grumble, of course. Germanyâ€™s crisis is not just a product of bad luck. Germany has made a series of strategic mistakes going back decades â€“ some of which are unforgivable and utterly inexplicable.

Like many in Europe, Germany misjudged Russiaâ€™s intentions. Indeed, even as President Putinâ€™s tanks massed on the Ukrainian border, Germany still had every intention of pressing ahead with Nord Stream 2, a planned gas pipeline to Russia, which would have supplied a third of Germanyâ€™s gas needs for the next decade. This reliance on piped gas also means that, unlike other countries, like the Netherlands and France, Germany has no infrastructure for importing liquefied natural gas, which would allow it to buy gas from a broader range of countries.

And like many countries, Germany has attempted a disastrous transition to carbon-free energy. The intermittency problems that are inherent to renewable energy mean there are huge energy gaps to fill when the sun doesnâ€™t shine or the wind doesnâ€™t blow. This creates a dependency on gas to fill in the gaps.

Most baffling of all has been Germanyâ€™s abandonment of nuclear power. Nuclear energy produces no carbon emissions, but it is still hated and feared by Germanyâ€™s green-leaning establishment. In fact, green thinking exercises such a tight grip on the German political class that the German government appears determined not to extend the lifespan of its nuclear power plants â€“ even amid this once-in-a-century energy crisis, and even as it asks for energy-rationing â€˜solidarityâ€™ from other countries.

The crippling gas cuts to come are not a sign of European strength and solidarity. They are an irrational, dangerous reaction to a crisis decades in the making. And they will leave a lot of ordinary Europeans out in the cold.
Fraser Myers

texts.text: is deputy editor at

text.text: spiked

texts.text: and host of
the

text.text: spiked podcast

texts.text: . Follow him on Twitter:

text.text: @FraserMyers
Picture by: Getty.

#Antifake

We have taken note of a new @SkyNews story on â€œRussian cyber spies targeting NATO countries.â€ Citing a report by a US cybersec company, the Sky News reporters made unsubstantiated claims that hacking attacks have been made against â€œseveral Western and NATO diplomatic missions.â€ 

The information provided in the UK journalistsâ€™ tall tales doesnâ€™t stand up to a momentâ€™s scrutiny. The report cited by Sky News only mentioned several cyberattacks against a certain NATO country. Can this be described as a large-scale Russian hacking attack against all Western countries? At the same time, the propaganda activists keep silent about the recommendations of Britainâ€™s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC), which has admitted publicly that the UK, a NATO member, has not been a target of major cyberattacks and has no evidence of concrete threats resulting from Russiaâ€™s actions.

 We look forward to more of the UK journalistsâ€™ slipshod stories.


#AntiFakeOfTheDay

 What can you tell us about the European Commissionâ€™s explanations, published today, for its decision to lift the cargo transit restrictions to/from the Kaliningrad Region?

ðŸ’¬  Yesterday, US National Security Advisor to the President Jacob Sullivan held a briefing for the media on President Bidenâ€™s upcoming visit to the Middle East. The main takeaway is that the Persian Gulf countries have the potential to significantly BOOST oil and gas production.

It seems they will soon be even more disappointedâ€¦

#Opinion by Maria Zakharova:

ðŸ’¬ Itâ€™s been fun to watch the government crisis in Britain unfold, with two key ministers resigning yesterday and five other high-ranking but less important politicians resigning shortly after.

The scandal revolves around recent drunken misconduct by former Minister of State for Europe and the Americas Conservative Christopher Pincher. Prime Minister Johnson now stands accused of being fully aware of Pincher's checkered past when he appointed him Deputy Chief Whip of the Conservative Party in parliament.

Many in Britain and elsewhere were shocked.

But those in the know saw it coming.

One of our diplomats who worked in Britain attended as an observer the Conservative Party conventions that traditionally brought together top Tories led by the prime minister. Our diplomatâ€™s eyes were wide with amazement when he returned. The party convention looked more like a drunken frat party. A Russian diplomat is unlikely to be spooked by excessive alcohol consumption, but British party officials didnâ€™t just lose their spatial orientation â€“ it was their human orientation, including sexual, too.

Well-dressed party activists start their mornings with high-end champagne. Then they switch to beer, which they drink in mind-boggling quantities. The parties start later in the afternoon with Tories going around the city emptying the liquor shelves of every bar.

The ruling Conservative Party has created nearly insurmountable economic hardships for ordinary hardworking Britons. 

No matter how often they repeat their â€œMoscow, Kremlin, Putinâ€ mantra, they are unable to distract the public. People know who brought the situation in Britain to the brink of collapse and even the risk of disunion. Some â€œparty.â€

Looks like Robbie Williams needs to sit down and write a new hit titled â€œParty like a Tory.â€

This problem is not ours. Itâ€™s a British problem. But London is trying to resolve its domestic problems by looking abroad and engaging in anti-Russian activities, provocations in Ukraine, global economic destabilisation, and financial piracy.

P.S. While I was writing this post, Children's Minister Will Quince resigned.

âš¡ï¸ Comment by Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova on Ukrainian Armed Forcesâ€™ strikes on residential areas of Belgorod and Kursk.

Video with ENG subs

ðŸ’¬ The goal of the Kiev regime is to strike the residential areas of cities with unguided weapons. This is far from the first time something similar has happened. 

We understand that these actions of the regime in Kiev were not only agreed upon with its western superintendents but were also most likely prompted by them. They do this to force us into striking back in a similar fashion so they can carry on hyping their anti-Russian hysteria. 

We have abstained from making such steps, but we will be monitoring these developments very carefully. Those who have been acting in this fashion should be aware that they will have to pay a hefty price should these provocations continue.

text.text: El presidente ruso Vladimir Putin habla en el Foro EconÃ³mico Internacional de San Petersburgo, Rusia, viernes 17 de junio de 2022. Foto: AP.
Â¿SurgirÃ¡n un G-8 o un G-10 mundiales?
Hedelberto LÃ³pez Blanch

Debido a las numerosas y prolongadas extorsiones que Estados Unidos y Occidente han impuesto a la FederaciÃ³n Rusa, estÃ¡n surgiendo nuevos centros econÃ³micos alternativos que apuestan por polÃ­ticas comerciales multipolares.

El presidente de la Duma estatal rusa Vyacheslav Volodin afirmÃ³ que Washington con su arbitraria polÃ­tica de sanciones ha creado las condiciones para que paÃ­ses con razones para rechazar esas medidas se estÃ©n uniendo y podrÃ­a surgir, lo que llamÃ³, el nuevo G-8 en contraposiciÃ³n al G-7.

Esas son las naciones que no participan en la llamada guerra de las mal denominadas â€œsancionesâ€: China, Rusia, Indonesia, Brasil, MÃ©xico, TurquÃ­a, India e IrÃ¡n, cuyo Producto Interno Bruto, en conjunto, suma 60 billones de dÃ³lares.
Mientras, el Grupo del G-7: Estados Unidos, CanadÃ¡, Francia, Gran BretaÃ±a, Italia, JapÃ³n y Alemania, solo llega a 45 billones de dÃ³lares, o sea, 25 % menor que el supuesto G-8.
A esos paÃ­ses habrÃ­a que agregar otros como Venezuela, SudÃ¡frica, Nigeria o Argentina, por ejemplo, que tienen grandes potencialidades.

Otras muchas naciones de Ãfrica, Asia y AmÃ©rica Latina tampoco se han plegado a las agresivas y absurdas medidas de Washington que pretende mantener una hegemonÃ­a polÃ­tica y econÃ³mica mundial pese a su constante declive en la arena internacional.

Esa polÃ­tica de extorsiones ha provocado una inflaciÃ³n generalizada en los alimentos en el mundo, debido a las restricciones para la adquisiciÃ³n de petrÃ³leo, gas, fertilizantes y otros productos de Rusia.

Por ejemplo, elÂ The New York TimesÂ titulÃ³: La inflaciÃ³n vuelve a acelerarse frustrando las esperanzas de alivio. La agencia Reuters publicaba: La inflaciÃ³n en Estados Unidos al rojo vivo aplasta las acciones europeas en medio de los temores de recesiÃ³n; y televisora CNBC seÃ±alaba: La fuerte inflaciÃ³n y la ansiedad de los consumidores aumentan la preocupaciÃ³n por la recesiÃ³n.

MoscÃº ha enfatizado que esa situaciÃ³n ha sido por los errores de Occidente al imponer â€œsancionesâ€ ilegÃ­timas, lo cual ha incidido en la inflaciÃ³n global; la destrucciÃ³n de las cadenas logÃ­sticas y de producciÃ³n; aumento de la pobreza y la escasez de alimentos.

La propaganda de Occidente, con el objetivo de convencer al pÃºblico de que la polÃ­tica de amonestaciones aplicada contra Rusia ha debilitado la economÃ­a de la naciÃ³n euroasiÃ¡tica ha quedado completamente descalificada.

En contraposiciÃ³n a las falsas noticias, el Ministerio de Desarrollo EconÃ³mico ruso enfatizÃ³ que el paÃ­s ha enfrentado esas restricciones, entre otras acciones, con el aumento de las operaciones con los paÃ­ses en vÃ­as de desarrollo, principalmente con el Grupo BRICS (Brasil, Rusia, India, China y SudÃ¡frica) al lograr un crecimiento del 38% en el primer trimestre del 2022.
Asimismo Rusia elevÃ³ el intercambio comercial con AmÃ©rica Latina: 2,3 % en abril y 2,5 % en junio.

El potencial del gigante euroasiÃ¡tico quedÃ³ demostrado en el reciÃ©n finalizado XXV Foro EconÃ³mico Internacional de San Petersburgo, que con la participaciÃ³n de 14 000 personas de 130 paÃ­ses se firmaron acuerdos por 5,6 billones de rublos, equivalentes a 98 000 millones de dÃ³lares.

El asesor de la presidencia rusa y secretario del ComitÃ© organizador del evento, AntÃ³n Kobiakov, informÃ³ que se signaron 691 acuerdos por valor de 5,639 billones de rublos, pero solo anunciaron los que no representan un secreto comercial. A buen entendedor, pocas palabras bastan.

Durante un discurso pronunciado en el Foro el presidente Vladimir Putin afirmÃ³ que la â€œÃ©poca del orden mundial unipolar ha finalizado pese a todos los intentos de conservarlo por cualquier medioâ€.

El estadista puntualizÃ³ que Washington parece no darse cuenta de que en las Ãºltimas dÃ©cadas se han ido formando y ganando terreno nuevos centros poderosos con sus propios sistemas polÃ­ticos e instituciones pÃºblicas, asÃ­ como modelos de crecimiento econÃ³mico que tienen derecho a su protecciÃ³n y a garantizar la soberanÃ­a nacional.
AgregÃ³ que el objetivo de las sanciones consistÃ­a en aplastar la economÃ­a rusa pero no ha tenido Ã©xito pues se estÃ¡ normalizando la situaciÃ³n econÃ³mica paso a paso.

Mientras en Europa, argumentÃ³, los pronÃ³sticos de los expertos indican que sumando solo las pÃ©rdidas directas de la UniÃ³n Europea como consecuencia de la â€œfiebre de sancionesâ€ contra Rusia, el costo de las medidas punitivas pueden superar los 400 000 millones de dÃ³lares.

Por Ãºltimo seÃ±alÃ³ que â€œla velocidad y la escala de los cambios en la economÃ­a global, las finanzas y las relaciones internacionales estÃ¡n aumentando y cada vez mÃ¡s se hace visible el rechazo a la globalizaciÃ³n a favor de un modelo de crecimiento multipolarâ€.
LlÃ¡mese G-8, G-10 o G-50, lo cierto es que un mundo unipolar ya no es posible.

Columnista de The Wall Street Journal tacha de "triplemente falsas" las acusaciones de Biden a Putin por el drÃ¡stico aumento de precios en EE.UU.

Las reiteradas declaraciones del presidente de EE.UU., Joe Biden, en las que culpa al mandatario ruso, VladÃ­mir Putin, por el drÃ¡stico aumento de los precios en el paÃ­s norteamericano, son "publicidad falsa por partida triple", asegurÃ³ el columnista del diario The Wall Street Journal Holman W. Jenkins Jr. en un artÃ­culo publicado este 21 de junio.

El autor seÃ±ala que el actual incremento de los precios del petrÃ³leo no empezÃ³ con el inicio del conflicto en Ucrania. "Por mucho que se hable de Ucrania, el 55 % del aumento actual desde el pasado diciembre se produjo antes de la invasiÃ³n rusa. Y lo que es mÃ¡s importante: la subida de la gasolina al por menor ha sido desproporcionadamente grande en relaciÃ³n con la subida subyacente del precio del petrÃ³leo", destacÃ³ Jenkins.

"Entonces, algo mÃ¡s estÃ¡ sucediendo y ese algo es un ajuste normal a un evento anormal: una pandemia mundial de dos aÃ±os que hizo caer la demanda de gasolina", indica el periodista, agregando que el coronavirus conllevÃ³ a "la paralizaciÃ³n de decenas de refinerÃ­as, especialmente en EE.UU.". webpage.title: Only 11% Of Americans Blame Putin's War In Ukraine For Oil Price Hike In US, Reveals Poll
webpage.description: In a blow for Joe Biden, a poll has revealed that only 11% of US citizens blame Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s war in Ukraine for a spike in oil prices.
webpage.author: Aanchal Nigam

text.text: Image: AP/Pixabay
Only 11% Of Americans Blame Putin's War In Ukraine For Oil Price Hike In US, Reveals Poll
In a blow for Joe Biden, a poll has revealed that only 11% of US citizens blame Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s war in Ukraine for a spike in oil prices.
Aanchal Nigam

texts.text: In the latest indication of Americans losing trust in US President Joe Bidenâ€™s leadership, a poll has revealed that only 11% of US citizens blame Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s war in Ukraine for a spike in oil prices. According to a Rasmussen poll published on Tuesday, the majority of people did not think that it is the

text.text: Russia-Ukraine war

texts.text: which caused the hike in oil prices instead, blamed Bidenâ€™s poor energy policies as the main reason why gas has become unaffordable in the United States.Â

text.text: The public opinion was uncovered by the poll weeks after Biden blamed â€œPutinâ€™s war in Ukraineâ€ for the oil price hike. However, the Americans who did not blame the Russian and US presidents placed the responsibility for the crisis on the oil companies. While 52% blamed Biden, at least 29% of the respondents suggested that the industry is leveraging the current geopolitical tensions due to the Russia-Ukraine war to jack up the prices.Â
Biden says its â€˜Putinâ€™s price hikeâ€™ in US

Putin announced the â€œspecialâ€ military operation in Ukraine in late February and to express support for Kyiv, the United States banned imports of Russian oil and gas in March. According to Russian state media RT, Moscow used to export only 2% Â of its oil to the US and Washington is the net gas exporter. However, earlier this month, Biden had levelled fresh blame on Putin for economic woes as US gas and diesel prices hit records per gallon. US President said it was â€œPutinâ€™s price hikeâ€.

â€œThe two challenges on the minds of most working families are prices at the pump and prices at the grocery store. Both of these challenges have been directly exacerbated by Putinâ€™s war in Ukraine,â€ Biden said in remarks near his vacation home in Rehoboth Beach, Del, â€œThe price of gas is up $1.40 since the beginning of the year when Putin began amassing troops at the Ukrainian border,â€ Biden added.
â€œThis is a Putin price hike. Putinâ€™s war has raised the price of food because Ukraine and Russia are two of the worldâ€™s major breadbaskets for wheat and corn,â€ he insisted.
Image: AP/Pixabay

ðŸš© On June 24, 1945, 77 years ago, the historical parade marking the USSRâ€™s victory in the GreatPatrioticWar over Nazi Germany was held on Moscowâ€™s Red Square.

Deputy Supreme Commander-in-Chief Georgy Zhukov, dubbed by the people â€˜Victory Marshalâ€™, was tasked with inspecting the parade, and Marshal of the Soviet Union Konstantin Rokossovsky commanded the parade.

The parade comprised 10 mixed regiments representing all the fronts that fought in the later stages of the Great Patriotic War. There were, in total, 24 marshals, 249 generals, 2,536 officers, 31,116 sergeants and soldiers, who distinguished themselves in combat and received orders and medals for their service.

The parade culminated when a column of soldiers carrying 200 trophy banners and standards of the defeated German army marched through Red Square and threw them at the foot of the Lenin Mausoleum.

Holding Victory Day Parades has become an annually-repeated tradition since 1995.

On June 16, 1963, Valentina Tereshkova performed her historic mission aboard Vostok-6, became the first woman in space. And to this day she remains the only female to have ever ventured to orbit solo. 

Launched from Baikonur Vostok-6 orbited the Earth 48 times and successfully landed in the Altai Territory. The flight took 2 days, 22 hours and 50 minutes. During the flight, Valentina Tereshkova took a series of pictures of the horizon, which was later used to detect aerosol levels in the atmosphere. 

Tereshkovaâ€™s space flight became a global sensation. Three days after the flight, she was awarded the title of Hero of the Soviet Union. Later on, she received the titles of Hero of Socialist Labour of Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Vietnam and Mongolia, and also became honorary citizen of 18 Russian and foreign cities.

US intelligence called on its British counterparts to activate networks of Afghan fighters. [â€¦]

messages.message:
Today marks the 239th Anniversary of the foundation of Sevastopol.
 It was on this day in 1783 that Rear Admiral Thomas MacKenzie ordered to lay the foundations of the first four stone structures in Sevastopol: a house for the commander of the Sevastopol naval squadron, a chapel, a smithy in the Admiralty, and a wharf, which was later given the name of Grafskaya.

 An important landmark in the contemporary history of Sevastopol was undoubtedly the March 16, 2014 Crimean referendum on the status of Crimea. As a result of the vote, 95.6% of referendum participants spoke in favour of the city joining the Russian Federation.

Today, the legendary Sevastopol retains its honorary title as the main base of Russiaâ€™s Black Sea Fleet, a city of martial glory and valour of Russian sailors.

Find out more

Key statements made by Director of the Economic Cooperation Department of the Russian Foreign Ministry Dmitry Bilichevsky during his briefing on global food security 

(June 10, 2022, Geneva)

The unfavourable situation on the global food market began to take shape a while ago, not since the beginning of Russia's special military operation. 

It dates back to February 2020 and is linked to the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic, when the world economy was "disoriented" and had to be restored.

Three reasons behind the current crisis

1ï¸âƒ£ US missteps in regulating its economy during the pandemic 

2ï¸âƒ£ EU overestimation of the alternative energy sources resulting in a dramatic price hike

3ï¸âƒ£ Irrational one-sided sanctions against Russia - one of the worldâ€™s leading food and energy producers 

ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¦ The current situation in Ukraine was also discussed. 

ðŸ“‘ READ THE FULL STATEMENT
Â¡Hola a todos! Â¡Feliz viernes!

#Opinion by Maria Zakharova:

ðŸ’¬ How many times do we have to explain who is responsible for the unfolding tragedy in the vegetable oil and grain markets? Still, the talking (not thinking) heads in Europe go through the same song and dance every day. Josep Borrell on Twitter once again blamed the global food crisis on â€œRussian missiles.â€ Who on earth writes this nonsense for him? 

Once again. In lay terms. The sanctions against the Russian Federation have dealt a serious blow to the global economy, which had only just begun to gradually recover from the crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The sanctions disrupted existing production, supply and logistics chains, and the payments system for our companies. We have a product â€“ grain â€“ while buyers have the money and the desire to buy it. But sanctions are preventing this from happening in a very simple way, both physically (transporting grain) and financially (paying for it).

This situation has harmed everyone. Disrupted supplies and payments have led to a global food shortage, contributed to a further increase in prices, and threatened global food security. No transactions mean decreased activity, and that combined with growing demand makes prices go up.

And yet, despite the objective transport and logistics difficulties, we remain global market participants in good standing. We fulfill and will continue to fulfill our obligations under international contracts regarding the export of grain, fertiliser, energy commodities and other critical products.

Unlike Europe, we are concerned about the unfolding food crisis. Western experts â€“ and even more so the leaders of developing countries â€“ understand the importance of Russian supplies of socially significant goods, including food, for the socioeconomic development of the countries of Asia, Africa, Latin America and the Middle East.

This is a flagrant Western hypocrisy.

Russia â€“ out of humanitarian considerations â€“ wants to ensure that Ukraine can provide itself with grain, including for planting. And what is the West doing? It is taking Ukrainian grain away by the truckload, leaving the Ukrainian population to struggle with the coming shortage. The West's actions undermine food security not only in Africa, but in Ukraine as well.

It seems that the vaunted expertise and intellectual capacity of our colleagues in Europe and America are now being used in the service of propaganda. Nothing too fancy, but they are expanding colossal energy to indoctrinate their population and convince them that the Russians are to blame. No other issues are discussed anymore, not even the economy or infrastructure. Indeed, why solve problems with food, electricity prices, their own inflation or other issues, including cybersecurity, space exploration safety, etc., when every problem can be blamed on the Russians?

â“ El Embajador de Rusia en Caracas, SerguÃ©i Melik-BagdasÃ¡rov, declarÃ³ que el Presidente de Venezuela habÃ­a sido invitado a efectuar una visita oficial a Rusia durante el aÃ±o en curso. Â¿EstÃ¡ preparÃ¡ndose esta visita?

ðŸ’¬ Alexander Shchetinin: Venezuela es nuestro socio estratÃ©gico confiable. En cuanto al Presidente NicolÃ¡s Maduro, siempre es bienvenido en MoscÃº.

â“ El periÃ³dico The Washington Post informÃ³ anteriormente que EEUU admitiÃ³ la posibilidad de levantar las sanciones contra el crudo de Venezuela. SegÃºn la informaciÃ³n del periÃ³dico, Washington intenta meter una cuÃ±a entre Rusia y Venezuela y resolver el problema con los precios de hidrocarburos. Â¿CÃ³mo estima MoscÃº un posible acercamiento de Washington y Caracas, puede EEUU ejercer con estas acciones una influencia real en la situaciÃ³n en el mercado energÃ©tico?

ðŸ’¬ Alexander Shchetinin: No solo The Washington Post, sino tambiÃ©n otros medios de comunicaciÃ³n populares comenzaron a publicar en mayo, como si hubieran recibido un encargo, la informaciÃ³n sobre los planes de la administraciÃ³n de Joe Biden de modificar el rÃ©gimen de sanciones contra Venezuela. AdemÃ¡s, la decisiÃ³n de extender la llamada licencia general de cinco empresas estadounidenses (Chevron, Halliburton, Schlumberger, Baker Hughes Ð¸ Weatherford International) publicada hace varios dÃ­as no prevÃ© algunas relajaciones.

Nuestra posiciÃ³n de principios no ha cambiado y la hemos manifestado sistemÃ¡ticamente en reiteradas ocasiones. Estamos a favor de eliminar todas las medidas restrictivas unilaterales impuestas por EEUU contra el Gobierno legÃ­timo de Venezuela liderado por NicolÃ¡s Maduro y de hecho contra este paÃ­s y su pueblo, por la normalizaciÃ³n de las relaciones entre Washington y Caracas sobre la base de la igualdad de derechos.
Â

Fue EEUU el que destruyÃ³ la interacciÃ³n eficaz con Caracas en el Ã¡mbito de suministros de hidrocarburos. Incrementando tenazmente la presiÃ³n de sanciones, impuso un embargo a la exportaciÃ³n del petrÃ³leo de Venezuela y la importaciÃ³n de productos petroleros a este paÃ­s. Se empujÃ³ consecuentemente a los venezolanos de la infraestructura financiera internacional, se les privÃ³ de los activos en el exterior, de las posibilidades de completar las pÃ©rdidas con prÃ©stamos en el mercado externo. Hasta durante la pandemia, el rÃ©gimen de sanciones impuesto por la Casa Blanca no se relajÃ³.

El hecho de que los estadounidenses hayan entrado en contacto directo con Caracas en las actuales circunstancias muestra claramente el oportunismo de su polÃ­tica exterior. Todo ese principio se desmoronÃ³ en cuanto la guerra econÃ³mica de Washington contra MoscÃº rebotÃ³ en la propia economÃ­a estadounidense. Esto es solo un ejemplo de las acciones de EEUU que llevaron a un desequilibrio en el mercado energÃ©tico global. Â

Nuestros contactos con los amigos de Caracas confirman que allÃ­ entienden muy buen â€œquiÃ©n es quiÃ©nâ€. Nuestra interacciÃ³n continÃºa y se desarrollarÃ¡ independientemente de las sanciones, sean las impuestas contra Venezuela o contra Rusia.
Â

â“ Se planea celebrar en Los Ãngeles del 6 al 10 de junio la Cumbre de las AmÃ©ricas, pero muchos paÃ­ses latinoamericanos no han tomado la decisiÃ³n todavÃ­a si participarÃ¡n en este evento o han renunciado a participar, varios Estados no han sido invitados por EEUU. Los Gobierno de la regiÃ³n resultaron divididos por el tema de Ucrania que EEUU y CanadÃ¡ quieren hacer central en la agenda. Â¿CÃ³mo es la postura de MoscÃº al respecto? Â¿Se puede constatar que esta iniciativa ha fracasado? Â¿En quÃ© medida logra Washington y Ottawa imponer a los paÃ­ses de AmÃ©rica Latina â€œsu voluntadâ€ en relaciÃ³n con Ucrania?
Â

ðŸ’¬ Alexander Shchetinin: Seguimos con atenciÃ³n la discusiÃ³n entre EEUU, CanadÃ¡ y los paÃ­ses de AmÃ©rica Latina y el Caribe en relaciÃ³n con la organizaciÃ³n y la agenda de la Cumbre de las AmÃ©ricas a celebrarse en Los Ãngeles. Vemos que son diversas las opiniones en relaciÃ³n con la propia cumbre y su agenda propuesta por los organizadores.
Â

Tenemos que constatar la aspiraciÃ³n de Washington a celebrar una discusiÃ³n ideologizada de los asuntos importantes para la regiÃ³n, hacer que responda a sus intereses en el Ã¡mbito de polÃ­tica exterior e interior. Esto fue reflejado, en particular, en la renuncia de EEUU a invitar a los representantes de tres Estados â€” Venezuela, Cuba y Nicaragua â€” a participar en la cumbre.
Â

QuisiÃ©ramos desear a los Estados de AmÃ©rica Latina con los que a nuestro paÃ­s unen histÃ³ricamente los estrechos lazos de amistad y cooperaciÃ³n mutuamente beneficiosa que en la prÃ³xima cumbre logren centrar la atenciÃ³n de sus participantes en la discusiÃ³n de la agenda regional real y la elaboraciÃ³n de las decisiones que respondan a los intereses de su desarrollo social y econÃ³mico y el fortalecimiento de la estabilidad polÃ­tica interna.
Â

â“ El Ministerio de Asuntos Exteriores de Rusia celebra regularmente reuniones para los Embajadores de los paÃ­ses extranjeros para explicar los objetivos de la operaciÃ³n militar especial y la situaciÃ³n en Ucrania. Se celebrÃ³ tal reuniÃ³n con los Embajadores de los paÃ­ses de AmÃ©rica Latina y el Caribe tambiÃ©n. Â¿CÃ³mo reaccionaron los paÃ­ses de esta regiÃ³n a la informaciÃ³n entregada por Rusia y cÃ³mo es su postura en relaciÃ³n con la situaciÃ³n actual en Ucrania, en general?
Â

ðŸ’¬ Alexander Shchetinin: EstamosÂ en contacto permanente, sincero y de confianza con los jefes de las representaciones diplomÃ¡ticasÂ de los Estados de AmÃ©rica Latina acreditados en MoscÃº. Este estilo de comunicaciÃ³n refleja el carÃ¡cter constructivo y amistoso de nuestras relaciones que destaca los vÃ­nculos ruso-latinoamericanos. Sostenemos un diÃ¡logo pragmÃ¡tico, no imponemos a ninguno de nuestros socios esquemas ideolÃ³gicos ni les obligamos a hacer una elecciÃ³n polÃ­tica: a quiÃ©n respaldar. Sabemos escuchar y oÃ­r a nuestros socios.
Â
Esto nos permite desarrollar la cooperaciÃ³n con vistas al futuro, fortalecer y ampliar el Ã¡rea de intereses mutuos en varios sectores que son muchos y tienen un carÃ¡cter objetivo y no sesgado.
Â

En cuanto a las valoraciones expresadas durante la comunicaciÃ³n de los altos cargos del Ministerio de Asuntos Exteriores de Rusia con los Embajadores acreditados en MoscÃº, quÃ© su contenido quede un elemento discreto del diÃ¡logo confidencial. Puedo asegurarles que su contenido fortalece la seguridad y contribuye al acercamiento de nuestros paÃ­ses.
Â
â“ Â¿Se sostienen contactos con AmÃ©rica Latina en relaciÃ³n con la seguridad alimentaria? Â¿Se han solicitado la ayuda a Rusia? Â¿Se elaboran algunas iniciativas conjuntas en esta Ã¡rea?
Â

ðŸ’¬ Alexander Shchetinin: Tales contactos se sostienen en diversas formas, naturalmente. En la coyuntura actual la necesidad de intensificar la cooperaciÃ³n en el Ã¡mbito de exportaciÃ³n e importaciÃ³n de los productos agrÃ­colas, garantizar los suministros regulares de fertilizantes minerales adquiriÃ³ una importancia especial. Rusia es un actor responsable del mercado global de alimentos y los latinoamericanos lo aprecian. AsÃ­ las cosas, se encontrarÃ¡n en conjunto las posibles soluciones mutuamente beneficiosas de todos los problemas que surgen Ãºltimamente.
Â
â“ En la comunidad de expertos se acepta y se discute la posibilidad de adhesiÃ³n a la OTSC de varios paÃ­ses de AmÃ©rica Latina. Â¿En quÃ© medida es real esta posibilidad, segÃºn usted?
Â
ðŸ’¬ Alexander Shchetinin: DejarÃ­a la discusiÃ³n de esta posibilidad hipotÃ©tica a los cÃ­rculos de expertos mencionados por usted si creen que existen algunos fundamentos para esto.
â“ Pasaron ya mÃ¡s de dos aÃ±os desde el periplo latinoamericano del Ministro de Asuntos Exteriores de Rusia, SerguÃ©i Lavrov. Â¿Se planean nuevas visitas del Ministro a AmÃ©rica Latina y el Caribe?
Â

ðŸ’¬ Alexander Shchetinin: El diÃ¡logo ruso-latinoamericano tiene carÃ¡cter intensivo, en particular, a nivel de Ministros de Asuntos Exteriores. Planeamos preservar e incrementar su intensidad. Les informaremos oportunamente sobre los eventos acordados con nuestros socios en la regiÃ³n.
Â

â“ Â¿CÃ³mo se desarrollan las negociaciones de Rusia con los paÃ­ses de AmÃ©rica Latina en relaciÃ³n con el uso de las monedas nacionales en los pagos comerciales? Â¿Se realiza de alguna manera la iniciativa de AmÃ©rica Latina en relaciÃ³n con una plena renuncia a los pagos en dÃ³lares y la creaciÃ³n de su propia moneda?
Â

ðŸ’¬ Alexander Shchetinin: Para reducir riesgos de sanciones para la cooperaciÃ³n econÃ³mica y comercial ruso-latinoamericana trabajamos consecuentemente en la introducciÃ³n de unos mecanismos alternativos a los occidentales: operaciones sin efectivo, el establecimiento de las relaciones de corresponsalÃ­a directas entre los bancos. Emprendemos otros esfuerzos en esta direcciÃ³n tambiÃ©n. Discutimos tales enfoques con nuestros socios regionales a nivel bilateral y multilateral, inclusive en el marco de compaginaciÃ³n de los intereses de los espacios de integraciÃ³n eurasiÃ¡tico y latinoamericano.
Â

Somos realistas. Tomamos en consideraciÃ³n los intereses de nuestros socios y su experiencia. Por supuesto, nos enfocamos en el resultado: la formaciÃ³n de un entorno propicio para la cooperaciÃ³n econÃ³mica y tecnolÃ³gica de beneficio mutuo.
Â

â“ Â¿Se discute la posibilidad de conexiÃ³n de los paÃ­ses de AmÃ©rica Latina al sistema de pagos MIR? Por ejemplo, anteriormente se divulgÃ³ la informaciÃ³n de que Venezuela y Cuba pueden comenzar a aceptar las tarjetas Mir (sistema de pago nacional de Rusia) ya en verano. Â¿Se han alcanzado algunos Ã©xitos en esta Ã¡rea?
Â
ðŸ’¬ Alexander Shchetinin: Tal actividad estÃ¡ realizÃ¡ndose. No establecerÃ­a unos plazos concretos. Espero que sus resultados concretos no se hagan esperar.

The main thing from the interview of President Vladimir Putin to Pavel Zarubin @kommersant

 Decent people in the United States, for example, the Secretary of the Treasury, admitted that they made mistakes, so there is a crisis.

 The short-sighted policy of European countries in the energy sector has led to a crisis. The West overestimated the possibilities of alternative energy. 

The situation with global fertilizers will worsen due to sanctions, and food prices will only go up. 

The fact that Russia does not allow Ukrainian grain to be exported is a bluff. We do not interfere with this, it can be exported through ports controlled by Ukraine or through Belarus.But then it is necessary to remove sanctions from Minsk.

 Ukrainian wheat located in ports does not have a serious impact on the world market. Russia is ready to increase grain exports in the next agricultural year from 37 million to 50 million tons. 

Russia will not use the situation of demining Ukrainian ports to launch attacks from the sea. The Russian Federation is ready to ensure the peaceful transportation of grain and the entry of ships to the Azov and Black Seas.

text.text: Man-Made Famine 2022

Representatives of the collective West members are tripping over each other as they scramble to accuse Russia of undermining global food security. The G7 has issued a special statement in this regard. To be sure, we responded.
Those most deeply concerned reinforced the choir by their solo performances.

The other day, German Federal Minister of Foreign Affairs Annalena Baerbock said on the sidelines of the G7 foreign ministersâ€™ meeting that the situation in Ukraine may trigger global famine. Before that, Joe Biden spoke in a similar vein, â€œThe American farmers understand Putinâ€™s war has cut off critical sources of food. <â€¦> If those tons [of grain] donâ€™t get to market, an awful lot of people in Africa are going to starve to death because they [Ukraine] are the sole supplier of a number of African countries.â€
That is, Russia is now to blame for famine in Africa. No one ever went hungry there before, as everyone knows.
It is easy to debunk this fake manufactured by Washington and its allies with numbers and facts.
Letâ€™s look at the situation from the perspective of economic experts.

Even before the special operation in Ukraine, international agricultural production was among the worst affected areas due to global economic instability. The current food market situation has been taking shape over at least the past two years. The commodity exchanges show that wheat prices grew by 25 percent in 2021 alone. By February, they were significantly above average prices in 2017-2021 (up to 62 percent). The price of corn has increased by 162 percent and rapeseed by 175 percent within a span of two years. Moreover, prices have retraced from their peak values. These are standard market price fluctuations, which are not unusual for the global grain markets in recent history.
Why have grain prices been rising over the past two years? There are several reasons behind that.

First, it was the COVID-19 pandemic which disrupted supply chains and increased freight and insurance costs. In 2020-2021, the developed economies sharply increased their financial injections into their respective economies in order to overcome the aftermath of the pandemic. The aggregate value of anti-crisis measures in the United States, the EU and Japan amounted to over $8 trillion, which drove the demand up and whipped up inflation (including food prices). The trend was further exacerbated by open trade wars between the key players and persistent sharp contradictions in the agricultural market regulations, which led to food stocks dropping to their lowest over the past 5 to10 years, sending grain prices higher. Moreover, freight rates have almost doubled.

Second, some Western countries hastened their transition to green energy in hopes of developing alternative energy sources at the expense of traditional fuels, which led to increased energy prices. In particular, oil prices in 2020-2022 grew by over 22 percent in the face of a drop in demand during austere pandemic-related restrictions. Natural gas prices have risen significantly as well. As a result, prices for mineral fertiliser went through the roof in December 2021. Prices for carbamide and saltpetre increased 3.5-4 times, and prices for other types of fertilisers surged 2.5-3 times. What do we need mineral fertiliser for? Thatâ€™s right, agriculture. The higher the price of fertilisers, the higher the price of a bushel of grain. As a reminder, all of that happened before February 24.

Third, the short-sighted and selfish policy of the developed Western countries has played its role. During the coronacrisis, the United States and Europe actually redirected commodity flows, including food flows, towards themselves, thus worsening the already difficult situation in developing countries that are dependent on food imports. The United States and Europe were buying increasing amounts of food that they did not really need, leaving nothing for the countries of Africa and Asia. The situation was further exacerbated by low food stocks, adverse weather and inadequate investment in this industry.

Amid rising fuel and fertiliser prices, farmers began to reduce the planted acreage across the board, which made agricultural produce increasingly scarce against the backdrop of ever-growing demand. A drop in supply amid growing demand means higher prices.

Fourth, the sanctions, which are of primary importance. The unilateral economic pressure measures imposed by the collective West on our country in February-March 2022 exacerbated the negative trends on the global food and energy markets and in the manufacturing industry. Payment restrictions and supply chain disruptions affected all economic operators, including agricultural companies, which ran into financial and transport difficulties when servicing food contracts. In the face of uncertainty, agricultural producers started questioning their choices concerning investment in expanding or even maintaining their operations. Some have decided to change how they do business, which further reduced supply on the market.

Unilateral sanctions, including threats of wide-sweeping arrests of dry cargo ships and disconnecting Russian financial institutions from SWIFT, have significantly exacerbated the problem of disrupted supply and financial chains involving Russian economic operators. Given Russiaâ€™s role in agricultural trade, this could not but affect the food supplies to our partners. Despite being fully aware of Russiaâ€™s role on the global agricultural market and of the challenging global food security situation, the West has nonetheless imposed sanctions affecting the agricultural sector and worsened the already distressing situation.
Washington, London and Brussels were not concerned about the fact that this could lead to malnutrition, even starvation, in certain parts of the world.

That said, even despite the difficulties manufactured by the West and in full accordance with the previously reached contractual agreements, the Russian Federation will continue to fulfil in good faith its obligations concerning the export of agricultural produce, fertilisers, energy and other critical products.

For many years now, we have been accused of creating threats to energy security and hearing claims that Russia is weaponising its gas supplies and can cut them off if it deems that something went wrong for it.

The â€œif somethingâ€ situation is here, but Russia continues its gas supplies. Those who intimidated the world with tales of the Russian energy switch, namely, Washington, are forcing everyone to say no to Russian gas.
So, who has created the threat to energy security? Ditto for the food.

text.text: Las duras pruebas que afectaron a los pueblos de la UniÃ³n SoviÃ©tica mostraron la grandeza del espÃ­ritu humano y generaron numerosos ejemplos de heroÃ­smo personal y colectivo y de verdadero patriotismo de nuestra gente.

text.text: liberaciÃ³n de los territorios de muchos Estados europeos

Se ha arraigado en la ideologÃ­a y los sÃ­mbolos del estado. La imponen a los medios de comunicaciÃ³n y a los polÃ­ticos.

En consecuencia, la desnazificaciÃ³n de este estado se convirtiÃ³ en un problema urgente hace una dÃ©cada y media, cuando empezaron a emitirse los decretos presidenciales sobre la glorificaciÃ³n de los lÃ­deres de la colaboraciÃ³n con los nazis (Stepan Bandera, Roman Shujevitch). text.text: la comunidad occidental sigue haciendo caso omiso

Este aÃ±o en la FederaciÃ³n de Rusia por la tradiciÃ³n se celebrarÃ¡ una seria de eventos: demostraciÃ³n de documentales y largometrajes de temÃ¡tica militar, conferencias, conciertos y la marcha millonaria del

text.text: â€œRegimiento Inmortalâ€

texts.text: (manifestaciones masivas en todo el paÃ­s de la gente que lleva en sus manos de manera simbÃ³lica las fotos de sus parientes y personas cercanas, que luchaban en la guerra o trabajaban en retaguardia suministrando todo lo necesario para la victoria en los campos de batalla). Por su parte la Embajada de Rusia en Uruguay organizarÃ¡ en su sede una exposiciÃ³n de afiches de los tiempos de la Gran Guerra Patria, asÃ­ comola marcha del â€œRegimiento Inmortalâ€ con participaciÃ³n de los miembros de las familias de los diplomÃ¡ticos y compatriotas rusos.Â

ðŸ“° El DÃ­a de la Gran Victoria: historia, lecciones y actualidad

Lean el artÃ­culo del Embajador ruso en Uruguay, Andrey Budaev, en el periÃ³dico Diario La R y la revista digital Tribuna Oriental.

ðŸ’¬ El 9 de mayo se conmemora el 77Âº Aniversario de la Victoria en la Gran Guerra Patria (Segunda Guerra Mundial) que fue el conflicto bÃ©lico mÃ¡s sangriento, mortal y desastroso en toda la historia de la humanidad. 61 Estados participaron en la conflagraciÃ³n, las acciones militares cubrÃ­an el territorio de 40 paÃ­ses, las pÃ©rdidas humanas sobrepasaron 50 millones, de los cuales 26 millones eran los ciudadanos de la UniÃ³n SoviÃ©tica.

<...>

â˜ï¸ En la situaciÃ³n actual es cada vez mÃ¡s importante conservar la verdad histÃ³rica, pasarla a las nuevas generaciones, a nuestros hijos(a)s y nieto(a)s, para que la tragedia de la Segunda Guerra Mundial no se repita en la historia de la humanidad.

Solo con esfuerzos conjuntos, con voluntad polÃ­tica y sentimientos francos y abiertos podremos lograr este propÃ³sito. La celebraciÃ³n del 77Â° Aniversario de la Gran Victoria no debe ser pretexto para la confrontaciÃ³n, ni servir para ajustar viejas cuentas o revivir ofensas mutuas. Lo contrario â€“ debe unir a paÃ­ses y pueblos para hacer frente comÃºn contra manifestaciones de neonazismo, sus ideÃ³logos y activistas.

ARTÃCULO COMPLETO

â—¼ï¸ El 2 de mayo se cumplen ocho aÃ±os de la terrible tragedia de Odesa.

En este dÃ­a de 2014, los neonazis ucranianos masacraron a aquellos que se habÃ­an levantado contra el golpe de estado en Ucrania, las nuevas polÃ­ticas de Kiev y el nacionalismo radical.

ðŸ•¯ 48 personas fueron quemadas vivas y mÃ¡s de 250 sufrieron heridas en el incendio en la Casa de los Sindicatos de la ciudad ucraniana de Odesa.

Ya han pasado 8ï¸âƒ£ aÃ±os, pero ninguno de los culpables ha sido castigado. Este acto bÃ¡rbaro sacudiÃ³ al mundo entero. Sin embargo, el Occidente "civilizado" guardÃ³ silencio de forma incivilizada.

â—ï¸ Nunca olvidaremos este crimen atroz y trabajaremos para identificar y llevar ante la justicia a los responsables.

ðŸ’¬ Canciller SerguÃ©i Lavrov: EEUU, como todos los demÃ¡s paÃ­ses que se jactan de ser democracias perfectas, ha firmado y ratificado la Carta de las Naciones Unidas, cuyo principio clave es la igualdad soberana de los Estados.

La Carta no dice que las democracias deban tener mÃ¡s derechos que las autocracias, dictaduras o monarquÃ­as. No dice que haya distinciÃ³n alguna en cuanto a los derechos que disfrutan los miembros de la ONU.

En este Ã³rgano de la ONU dichos paÃ­ses pueden alcanzar la mayorÃ­a de votos con chantajes y amenazas a las delegaciones participantes, lo que crea una tendencia peligrosa.

#Opinion by Russian MFA Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova

Nuclear DisInfo (Read in full)

Mechanisms for information attacks with a new thesis that target the public space have been launched in the West at the highest level in a transboundary and trans-format manner. The premise is primitive and completely horrifying: the Russians are threatening a nuclear war, and the Russians are waving the nuclear stick.

â‰ï¸ Do I even need to say that this thesis is absolutely incorrect and false? Apparently, I do.

They are pushing this exact thesis because it plays on basic human fears, the experience of the older generation, which throughout the second half of the 20th century was bracing for the Third World War against global communism, and Western youth, for which their respective governments have come up with a new mechanism called â€œcancel cultureâ€ (cancelling everything Russian this time). Moreover, the West absolutely does not care what Moscow really says, and the meaning of words is distorted and outwardly perverted.

Letâ€™s consider the specifics.

Two days ago, in his answer to a question by Dimitri Simes during an interview, Sergey Lavrov said literally the following ðŸ‘‰ full quote

What are the takeaways?

1. It was Russia that, with great difficulty, convinced the United States during lengthy talks to reaffirm the Gorbachev-Reagan formula that a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought.

2. It was Russia that persuaded the group of five nuclear nations to adopt a statement with the same content.

3. There are risks; they should not be blown out of proportion or underestimated.

We did everything possible to prevent a nuclear war, to create all the necessary obstacles on the way to slipping into this scenario (fortunately, they justified themselves during the Cold War and are working today), because we understand the real risks and threats posed by irresponsible behaviour in this area. We cannot allow the very thought of a nuclear war.

Now acting in the worst traditions of disinformation, Western officials are feeding the media, in a coordinated effort, fake news about Moscowâ€™s alleged nuclear threats. The foreign ministries from the NATO countries started convincing the people in their countries that the Russians were â€œrattling their weapons.â€

<...>

Notice how clumsy this was in terms of media work. First, all the put-up quotes against our country were repeated by the journalist, and then they were again mentioned by Ned Price. A presentation designed for a not too sophisticated public. No one even paid attention to what the Foreign Minister said about the risks and Russiaâ€™s attempts to prevent the unthinkable.

Itâ€™s unthinkable to us, but, mindful of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, it is, unfortunately, possible for our colleagues from overseas.

The next day, the media started mass brainwashing. The British tabloids (the Daily Mail and others) and the high-quality analytical US press, French television and German tabloid magazines started talking with one voice that Moscow was threatening with a Third World Nuclear War. And this was already being discussed in Europe; French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian said that the Russian Foreign Ministerâ€™s words were the â€œrhetoric of intimidation.â€  

I would like to ask this Frenchman whether he at least saw what Sergey Lavrov said? We have translated the interview.

Our country is against any nuclear war, and this is exactly what the Russian Minister said, and this is what guides our diplomacy in its work.

Could it be that the Western capitals read the interviews as presented by the Western media? This is the only thing that can justify their words. To avoid that, one should simply DON'T turn off alternative sources of information, and listen to what Russia has to say close to the original text, rather than as interpreted by your media under NATO guidelines.

Mechanisms for information attacks with a new thesis that target the public space have been launched in the West at the highest level in a transboundary and trans-format manner. The thesis is primitive and completely horrifying: the Russians are threatening a nuclear war, and the Russians are waving the nuclear stick.
Â
Do I even need to say that this thesis is absolutely incorrect and false? Apparently, I do.
Â

They are pushing this exact thesis because it plays on basic human fears, the experience of the older generation, which throughout the second half of the 20th century was bracing for the Third World War against global communism, and Western youth, for which their respective governments have come up with a new mechanism called â€œcancel cultureâ€ (cancelling everything Russian this time). Moreover, the West absolutely does not care what Moscow says, and the meaning of words is distorted and outwardly perverted.
Letâ€™s consider the specifics.

texts.text: Two days ago, in his answer to a question by Dimitri Simes during an interview, Sergey Lavrov

text.text: said

texts.text: literally the following:

text.text: â€œFor many years, as far back as during the Donald Trump presidency, we called for Moscow and Washington to reaffirm at the highest level the 1987 statement by Mikhail Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan, who said that a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. We tried to convince Donald Trumpâ€™s team to reaffirm this statement, considering its importance for our nations and for the entire world. Unfortunately, we failed to persuade our colleagues that this step was needed. However, we reached common ground with the Joe Biden administration quite quickly, and our presidents issued the statement in June 2021 during their Geneva summit. In January 2022, we fulfilled another initiative to this effect. The five permanent members of the UN Security Council adopted a statement along the same lines, which was supposed to coincide with the opening of the Review Conference of the Parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. All five leaders put their signatures under the statement that a nuclear war must never happen. This is our position of principle, and we are committed to it. The risks are quite high today. I would not like to see them blown out of proportion, but many would love to do it. This threat is serious and real.â€
Â
What are the takeaways?
Â
1. It was Russia that, with great difficulty, convinced the United States during lengthy talks to reaffirm the Gorbachev-Reagan formula that a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought.
2. It was Russia that persuaded the group of five nuclear nations to adopt a statement with the same content.
3. There are risks; they should not be blown out of proportion or underestimated.
Â

We did everything possible to prevent a nuclear war, to create all the necessary obstacles on the way to slipping into this scenario (fortunately, they justified themselves during the Cold War and are working today), because we understand the real risks and threats posed by irresponsible behaviour in this area. We cannot allow the very thought of a nuclear war.
Â

Acting in the worst traditions of disinformation, Western officials are feeding the media, in a coordinated effort, fake news about Moscowâ€™s alleged nuclear threats. The foreign ministries from the NATO countries started convincing the people in their countries that the Russians were â€œrattling their weapons.â€
Â

First, the media waylaid US Secretary of Defence Lloyd Austin in Germany and later quoted him as saying that â€œthe Russians are threatening us with a bomb.â€ Then, CIA Director William Burns spoke to the same topic in Atlanta. At the same time, retirees, including former US Secretary of Energy Ernest Moniz, were pulled out of mothballs to continue to flood the discourse with the â€œRussian atomic threat.â€
Â

texts.text: All of that was a warm-up to US State Department Spokesperson Ned Price calling the Russian Ministerâ€™s words â€œblusterâ€ and at the same time, paradoxically, positing a â€œpotential nuclear escalationâ€ during a

text.text: briefing

Notice how clumsy this was in terms of media work. First, all the put-up quotes against our country were repeated by the journalist, and then they were again mentioned by Ned Price. A presentation designed for a not too sophisticated public. No one even paid attention to what the Foreign Minister said about the risks and Russiaâ€™s attempts to prevent the unthinkable.

Itâ€™s unthinkable to us, but, mindful of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, it is, unfortunately, possible for our colleagues from overseas.

by Maria Zakharova

 Boris Johnson has urged the Russian government to treat the Briton detained in Mariupol while fighting on the side of the Ukrainian government forces â€œhumanely and compassionately.â€

Here is what we have to say in this respect. 

Boris, we know that you personally and your Government have disavowed the British subjects who have fallen victim to British propaganda and went to Ukraine as mercenaries to kill people there. 

Donâ€™t pretend to be worried. You are utterly unconcerned about the fate of Britons in trouble. They didnâ€™t drink champagne with you at Downing Street, and so they can wait for your protection till kingdom come. 

I would like to tell the following to those Britons who are concerned about their compatriots: Donâ€™t worry, Russia is taking care of them. They are given food and drink, as well as any other assistance they may need, just as the other foreigners who have surrendered or have been detained.

Unlike the Ukrainian fighters who brutally kill prisoners and torture civilians, the Russian Armed Forces are committed to humanitarian law. If there were no media censorship in Britain, everyone there would know this.

At the same time, we urge the British authorities to treat the citizens of Ukraine â€œhumanely and compassionately,â€ as Boris Johnson said, by stopping the delivery of weapons to Ukraine. The more weapons London is sending to Ukraine, the more citizens of Ukraine die as a result. But the BBC will never tell Britons about that.

ðŸ‡·ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ðŸ‡¦ðŸ“ž On April 16, Russian President Vladimir Putin had a telephone conversation with Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia Mohammed bin Salman Al Saud, at the initiative of the Saudi side.

The Leaders discussed current issues of bilateral cooperation, including in trade and the economy, and expressed their commitment to further developing mutually beneficial ties between Russia and Saudi Arabia.

ðŸ¤  They spoke highly of the joint work in the OPEC Plus format aimed at ensuring the stability of the global oil market.

The Leaders also exchanged opinions on some topics on the international agenda, including the situation around Ukraine and Yemen settlement.

â˜ªï¸ Vladimir Putin congratulated the leaders and people of Saudi Arabia on the Muslim Holy Month of Ramadan. It was agreed to maintain contact at different levels.

â—ï¸Russia has made public the facts that have come to light to date at the UN and other international organisations and called on the US authorities to provide detailed explanations, but, predictably, Washington does not appear to be ready to share with the public any meaningful information on its military biological programme in Ukraine.

ðŸ“ƒ According to confirmed reports, Germany closely coordinated its work on biological security with its US allies, who established a network of at least 30 biological laboratories in Ukraine.

Read in full

â˜ï¸ We urge German officials to immediately stop spreading false allegations about our countryâ€™s intentions to use weapons banned by international law. We believe that such statements can only serve to push neo-Nazi battalions to commit horrible provocations, and moral responsibility for their tragic consequences will be shared by Berlin.

Ð˜Ð½Ñ‚ÐµÑ€ÐµÑÐ½Ð¾, ÐºÐ°Ðº Ð´Ñ€ÐµÐ²ÐµÑÐ¸Ð½Ñƒ Ð¸ ÑƒÐ´Ð¾Ð±Ñ€ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ Ð±ÑƒÐ´ÑƒÑ‚ Ð´ÐµÐ»Ð°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð½ÐµÑ€ÑƒÑÑÐºÐ¸Ð¼Ð¸?

By Maria Zakharova:

 We have been saying for the past eight years that the West is training Ukrainian nationalists. The â€œexceptionalâ€ and â€œcivilisedâ€ countries refused to listen, but we continued to make our point with facts in hand. That was easy: you only had to go to Ukraine to see the regular events involving SS Waffen veterans, torchlight marches and the huge portraits of Nazi accomplices on buildings in Ivano-Frankovsk, Lvov and Ternopol.

This week, Canadian correspondent Simon Coutu published the results of a simple investigation on his page at Radio Canada. He studied the pictures posted to social media by the National Guard of Ukraine and compared them to the training programmes conducted for the Ukrainian military by the Canadian Department of National Defence. What did he see?

He writes that many photographs made at the Canada-sponsored training centre in Zolochyov show men in fatigues with the symbols of SS divisions Das Reich and Galizien on their sleeve patches. The experts Coutu contacted have confirmed that these men are neo-Nazis, most probably from the Azov regiment.  Moreover, Coutu writes that the Azov Regiment has been incorporated into the Ukrainian National Guard as â€œa special detachment of Military Unit 3057.â€  He also found out that Canada has spent nearly a $1 billion on training the Ukrainian military since 2014. How much of these funds went to train neo-Nazis? Itâ€™s anybodyâ€™s guess.

â˜ï¸ As I have said, the Canadian journalist has simply looked at the pictures and has seen what we have been talking about for years. He just looked at the photographs. We call for this every day.

Do you understand now why Russian film director Elem Klimov named his film about Nazism â€œCome and Seeâ€? Sometimes that is all that is needed. But it turns out that even this takes a great deal of courage.
